description.narrative:
Cambodia Indigenous Youth Association (CIYA) is an indigenous-youth based organization in Cambodia. CIYA works directly and indirectly with Indigenous community in response to the indigenous issues and strengthening Indigenous communities# capacity through capacity building and community organizing for protection of forest, livelihoods and natural resources aiming at sustaining their livelihoods. Through Inclusion Project, CIYA implements the project called "Strengthening the Indigenous Community to Protect their Rights to Land and Natural Resources for Sustainable Development." The goal of the project is to protect the rights of local community, especially indigenous people through raising awareness to community in Kratie and Stung Treng on water governance related issues, especially impacts of hydro-power dams on the Mekong.
CIYA#s strategy plan 2014-2018 mainly focuses on capacity building and empowerment of indigenous communities and provincial members' networks. So, through the continuation of this project and experiences gaining from the previous project implementation, CIYA will try its best to engage its members in the project implementation through keeping good connection with different indigenous communities and different indigenous youth groups such as Bunong, Kui, Kreung, Prov, and Jarai who are living close to/in the affected areas. With respect to this, CIYA also builds a strong indigenous youth network in the target areas in each province as having seen that these groups are the most important human resources to help implement activities of the project. CIYA is implementing the project named #Strengthening the Indigenous Community to Protect their Rights to Land and Natural Resources for Sustainable Development.# The project goad is topromote the rights to land, territories and natural resources of Indigenous Peoples are strongly respected and protected under the national and international laws by governments, private sectors andrelevant stakeholders at local, national, regional and international levels.
The specific objective of the project is that #Community people in 9 villages Stung Treng province have accessed to relevant information on the proposed Stung Treng and Sekong hydropower dam projects as well as gained more knowledge on relevant law and policies, so that they are able to bring their issues to public and decision maker.# In this regard CIYA will work directly with 500 (300 female) direct beneficiaries and 1000 (500 female) indirect beneficiaries including women, men,youth and indigenous people around awareness raising, capacity building, networking, facilitating dialogues related to national and international legal framework promoting rights to natural resource management.

participating-org.narrative: Cambodia Indigenous Youth Association (CIYA) is the only indigenous youth network registered and active in Cambodia at both grass-root and national level. It was formed in 2005 by a group of indigenous peoples students and officially registered under Ministry of Interior in 2008. CIYA vision is to see indigenous peoples are strong, prosperous, and able to protect their natural resources, traditions, cultures, and rights. Developing the capacity of indigenous youths, who are the key human resources and future of the indigenous people, will help contribute towards sustaining their traditional livelihoods. Its mission are to 1/ consolidate all indigenous youths of both sexes studying in Phnom Penh and other provinces towards building a strong network. This will help strengthen their solidarity and allow them to build strong capacities, empowering them as the future generation of the indigenous communities they represent and 2/ helping indigenous communities in ensuring the protection and security of their land and natural resources in order to improve their livelihood and access to healthcare, and to maintain their identities such as custom, tradition, beliefs and languages.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to a sustainable livelihood

description.narrative: Oxfam Australia funding with back donor
